title: CMC Markets hit by lower market volatility
text:
CMC Markets has warned that lower market volatility has been taking its toll on earnings.

Overall monthly active client numbers are still up around a third from pre-pandemic levels but market activity was subdued through July and August, the broker said. It also cautioned that client income retention has been tracking “moderately” below target.

CMC said to expect net operating income of between £250m and £280m for the full year ending March. Its first-quarter update in July had targeted 2022 net operating income in excess of £330m.

Briefly

JD Sports' takeover of UK rival Footasylum could lead to a worse deal for shoppers so cannot progress, the Competition and Markets Authority said in a provisional ruling. Retailer JD said in a lengthy statement that it remains committed to the deal and “will continue to make our case strongly” to the CMA before it releases its final report in October.

Housebuilder Barratt Developments said recent sales have remained strong even after the withdrawal of tax breaks for buyers, with net private reservations per average week of 277 compared with 314 per week in the financial year ended June. Barratt posed a full year pre-tax profit of £812.2m, from £491.8m the year before, on revenue up 40.7 per cent to £4.8bn.

Engineer Melrose Industries said trading has been ahead of expectations amid a recovery for all its business lines. The group, which owns aerospace and automotive parts maker GKN, posted a half-year adjusted operating profit of £223m compared with an £11m loss a year ago.

EnQuest, the North Sea oil company, said it expects annual production to be at the lower end of its target range of between 46,000 and 52,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. Higher oil prices meant Enquest's half-year ebitda rose to $345.4m from $320.8m a year earlier in spite of falling production.

Holiday company Jet2 said winter season bookings have remained slow but are more encouraging for summer 2022, with average load factors at the same point ahead of summer 2019.

Gym Group said it expects increases in membership levels in September and October as students return to universities ahead of the peak new-year trading period. The company reported a half-year adjusted loss of £20.9m on revenue down 21.4 per cent to £29.3m. A £30.3m cash call in May helped reduce debt to £30.1m.

Beyond the Square Mile

Private equity groups Advent International and GIC have agreed to buy Stockholm-listed drugmaker Swedish Orphan Biovitrum for about $8bn. The consortium offered 235 Swedish krona per share, a 34.5 per cent premium to the stock's closing price on Wednesday. Sobi's board unanimously recommended that shareholders accept the offer.

Eurozone government bonds are showing signs that investors think the European Central Bank may begin winding down its emergency bond-buying programme as soon as this month. Germany's 10-year bond yield, a benchmark for euro area debt, rose to its highest in more than a month.

YouTube's paid music streaming services reached 50m subscribers in August, according to two people briefed on the figures — a milestone for Google as it competes with Amazon, Apple and Spotify in the competitive market.

Apple said it would loosen strict payment rules for certain app developers including Netflix and Spotify, allowing them to include links to their websites that would enable the companies to bypass the fees imposed by the iPhone maker. The concession was prompted by an investigation into Apple's App Store by the Japan Fair Trade Commission but will apply globally.

Members of the Sackler family who own Purdue Pharma have been granted immunity from future opioid lawsuits after a US judge approved a bankruptcy settlement for the drugmaker.

Essential comment before you go

Bryce Elder
A takeover approach for software maker Blue Prism continues US private equity's raid on corporate Britain. But public market investors have been cynical about the tech pioneer, leaving it at a competitive disadvantage, so maybe a retreat to private ownership is the best solution.

John Lee
To improve financial literacy the relationship — or lack of it — between TV and our savings and investment industry needs to be totally rethought. How can it be right that betting and gaming adverts are allowed on television, yet financial advertising is effectively banned because the conditions are too onerous?
